user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 1.2 is: Language extensions should not be used.
You should report only when the code uses any language compiler extensions that are explicitly stated as an extension in compiler documentations.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_CountSemCreate_Impl:
```c
int32 OS_CountSemCreate_Impl(const OS_object_token_t *token, uint32 sem_initial_value, uint32 options)
{
    OS_impl_countsem_internal_record_t *impl;

    impl = OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(OS_impl_count_sem_table, *token);

    if (sem_initial_value > SEM_VALUE_MAX)
    {
        return OS_INVALID_SEM_VALUE;
    }

    if (sem_init(&impl->id, 0, sem_initial_value) < 0)
    {
        return OS_SEM_FAILURE;
    }

    return OS_SUCCESS;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function OS_CountSemCreate_Impl:
#define OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(tbl, tok) (&tbl[OS_ObjectIndexFromToken(&(tok))])
...
OS_impl_countsem_internal_record_t OS_impl_count_sem_table[OS_MAX_COUNT_SEMAPHORES]
...
typedef struct
{
    sem_t id;
} OS_impl_countsem_internal_record_t
...
typedef struct OS_object_token OS_object_token_t
...
typedef int32_t   int32
...
typedef uint32_t  uint32
...
#define OS_INVALID_SEM_VALUE (-20)
...
#define OS_SEM_FAILURE (-6)
...
#define OS_SUCCESS (0)
...
static inline osal_index_t OS_ObjectIndexFromToken(const OS_object_token_t *token)
{
    return token->obj_idx;
}
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: I found no use of compiler-specific language extensions in the provided code. The function and related definitions use standard C constructs and POSIX semaphore APIs: typedefs, macros, array declaration, pointer dereference, address-of, and a static inline function (standard C). There are no occurrences of known compiler extensions such as __attribute__, __asm__, inline assembler, typeof, statement-expressions ({ ... }) used as an expression, nested functions, __extension__, nonstandard storage-class specifiers, or other vendor-specific keywords. The POSIX types/functions (sem_t, sem_init, SEM_VALUE_MAX) are standard OS API usage rather than compiler language extensions, so they do not trigger MISRA C:2023 Rule 1.2. Therefore no fragments need investigation for language-extension use.
